problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items to be placed in the box

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used to pack all items, minimized in objective
Assignment of each item to a box
X and Y positions of each item within its assigned box

constraints:
# -- Constraints --


# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def items_fit_exactly_in_boxes(
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    positions: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Position)
):
    # Ensure each item fits within the dimensions of the box it's assigned to
    for i in range(1, 11):
        box_id: int = assignments[i].box_id
        pos_x: int = positions[i].x
        pos_y: int = positions[i].y
        item_width: int = items[i].width
        item_height: int = items[i].height
        
        # Check that the item does not exceed the box boundaries
        assert pos_x + item_width <= BOX_WIDTH
        assert pos_y + item_height <= BOX_HEIGHT

items_fit_exactly_in_boxes(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, x_y_positions)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap_between_items(
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    positions: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Position)
):
    for i in range(1, 11):
        for j in range(i + 1, 11):
            # Only check overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i].box_id == assignments[j].box_id:
                x1: int = positions[i].x
                y1: int = positions[i].y
                w1: int = items[i].width
                h1: int = items[i].height

                x2: int = positions[j].x
                y2: int = positions[j].y
                w2: int = items[j].width
                h2: int = items[j].height

                # Assert that the two items do not overlap
                assert (
                    x1 + w1 <= x2 or
                    x2 + w2 <= x1 or
                    y1 + h1 <= y2 or
                    y2 + h2 <= y1
                )

no_overlap_between_items(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, x_y_positions)

# --- constraints ---
def each_item_in_exactly_one_box(
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
):
    # Ensure that each item is assigned to exactly one box
    # This is implicitly satisfied by the structure of assignments list
    # Each index corresponds to one item and holds one box assignment
    # No additional constraint needed; handled by data structure
    for i in range(1, 11):
        assert assignments[i].box_id >= 1
        assert assignments[i].box_id <= 10

each_item_in_exactly_one_box(item_box_assignments)
full_formulation:
# --- Objects ---


# Define the Item object type
Item = DSRecord({
    "width": DSInt(lb=1, ub=21),
    "height": DSInt(lb=1, ub=7)
})

# Define the BoxAssignment object type for tracking which box an item is assigned to
BoxAssignment = DSRecord({
    "box_id": DSInt(lb=1, ub=10)
})

# Define the Position object type for tracking x,y positions of items
Position = DSRecord({
    "x": DSInt(lb=0, ub=21),
    "y": DSInt(lb=0, ub=7)
})



# --- Constants and Decision Variables ---
BOX_HEIGHT : int = 8
BOX_WIDTH : int = 22
ITEMS : DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item) = [{"width": 2, "height": 2}, {"width": 8, "height": 3}, {"width": 5, "height": 4}, {"width": 15, "height": 1}, {"width": 12, "height": 4}, {"width": 21, "height": 5}, {"width": 19, "height": 2}, {"width": 4, "height": 7}, {"width": 18, "height": 5}, {"width": 14, "height": 7}]
nr_used_boxes : DSInt(lb=1, ub=10)
item_box_assignments : DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
x_y_positions : DSList(length=10, elem_type=Position)
N_ITEMS : int = 10
N_ITEM_BOX_ASSIGNMENTS : int = 10
N_X_Y_POSITIONS : int = 10


# --- objective ---
def calculate_objective(assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)) -> DSInt(lb=1, ub=10):
    max_box_id: int = 0
    for i in range(1, 11):
        if assignments[i].box_id > max_box_id:
            max_box_id = assignments[i].box_id
    return max_box_id

objective = calculate_objective(item_box_assignments)
nr_used_boxes = objective
minimize(objective)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---

        item_height: int = items[i].height

        assert pos_y + item_height <= BOX_HEIGHT

items_fit_exactly_in_boxes(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, x_y_positions)

    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    positions: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Position)
):
    for i in range(1, 11):
        item_width: int = items[i].width
        item_height: int = items[i].height
        pos_x: int = positions[i].x
        pos_y: int = positions[i].y
        # Ensure item fits within box dimensions

items_fit_exactly_in_assigned_boxes(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, x_y_positions)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap_in_same_box(
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    positions: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Position),
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item)
):
    for i in range(1, 11):
        for j in range(i + 1, 11):
            # Only check items in the same box
            same_box: bool = assignments[i].box_id == assignments[j].box_id
            if same_box:
                # Extract values for readability within constraint
                xi: int = positions[i].x
                yi: int = positions[i].y
                wi: int = items[i].width
                hi: int = items[i].height
                xj: int = positions[j].x
                yj: int = positions[j].y
                wj: int = items[j].width
                hj: int = items[j].height
                # No overlap condition: one must be to the left, right, above, or below the other
                assert (xi + wi <= xj) or (xj + wj <= xi) or (yi + hi <= yj) or (yj + hj <= yi)

no_overlap_in_same_box(item_box_assignments, x_y_positions, ITEMS)

    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
):
    for i in range(1, 11):
        assert assignments[i].box_id >= 1
        assert assignments[i].box_id <= 10

each_item_in_one_box(item_box_assignments)

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

X and Y positions of each item within its assigned box

def items_do_not_overlap(
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    positions: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Position)
):
    for i in range(1, 11):
        for j in range(i + 1, 11):
            # Only check overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i].box_id == assignments[j].box_id:
                # Extracting values for readability (but not as variables)
                xi = positions[i].x
                yi = positions[i].y
                wi = items[i].width
                hi = items[i].height
                xj = positions[j].x
                yj = positions[j].y
                wj = items[j].width
                hj = items[j].height
                
                # Non-overlapping condition: either:
                # - item i is to the right of item j: xi >= xj + wj

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

):

        item_height: int = items[i].height

                x1: int = positions[i].x

                assert (

    "x": DSInt(lb=0, ub=22),
    "y": DSInt(lb=0, ub=8)
})



# --- Constants and Decision Variables ---

BOX_WIDTH : int = 22
ITEMS : DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item) = [{"width": 2, "height": 2}, {"width": 8, "height": 3}, {"width": 5, "height": 4}, {"width": 15, "height": 1}, {"width": 12, "height": 4}, {"width": 21, "height": 5}, {"width": 19, "height": 2}, {"width": 4, "height": 7}, {"width": 18, "height": 5}, {"width": 14, "height": 7}]
N_ITEMS : int = 10
nr_used_boxes : DSInt(lb=1, ub=10)
item_box_assignments : DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
x_y_positions : DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
N_ITEMS : int = 10
N_ITEM_BOX_ASSIGNMENTS : int = 10
N_X_Y_POSITIONS : int = 10


# --- objective ---
def calculate_objective(assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)) -> DSInt(lb=1, ub=10):
    max_box_id: int = 0
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        if assignments[i].box_id > max_box_id:
            max_box_id = assignments[i].box_id
    return max_box_id

objective = calculate_objective(item_box_assignments)
nr_used_boxes = objective
minimize(objective)

# Leave empty, if not required.

def items_fit_in_box(
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    positions: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Ensure item fits within box dimensions
        assert positions[i].x + items[i].width <= BOX_WIDTH
        assert positions[i].y + items[i].height <= BOX_HEIGHT

        # Ensure item is placed in the assigned box (redundant check since box_id is same in both)
        assert assignments[i].box_id == positions[i].box_id

minimize(objective)
items_fit_in_box(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, x_y_positions)

# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap(
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check overlap if both items are in the same box
            if positions[i].box_id == positions[j].box_id:
                # Check for non-overlapping on x-axis
                x_not_overlap: bool = (positions[i].x + items[i].width <= positions[j].x) or \
                                      (positions[j].x + items[j].width <= positions[i].x)
                # Check for non-overlapping on y-axis
                y_not_overlap: bool = (positions[i].y + items[i].height <= positions[j].y) or \
                                      (positions[j].y + items[j].height <= positions[i].y)
                # Assert that at least one axis does not overlap
                assert x_not_overlap or y_not_overlap

no_overlap(ITEMS, x_y_positions)

):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        assert assignments[i].box_id >= 1
        assert assignments[i].box_id <= 10

ensure_item_in_one_box(item_box_assignments)

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.
